page.title: 14HOUSING_POYNTINGTON AREA
page.content: In the main the{old houses}and cottages are built of stone quarried locally and there are several disused quarries in the area.Of note is the {Tudor Manor}in Poyntington,where Sir Walter Raleigh was a freqent visitor. Also in that village is a large tithe barn,now converted into an attractive residence.The hamlet of Milborne Wick once boasted two watermills.One wheel remains as part of a water gardens at Manor Farm.An isolated crescent of farm cottages,known as Waterloo Crescent,built to commemorate the battle,remains vitually unaltered from the exterior,though modernised within. In both villages many old houses, cottages and farm buildings have been converted to modern residences without losing their old world charm.Building of new houses is under strict{planning control.
